Definition: A contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses, leading to symptoms like fever, cough, and body aches
A bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs but can spread to other organs.
Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) attacks the immune system, progressing to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) if untreated.
A mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Plasmodium parasites, characterized by fever, chills, and flu-like symptoms.
A viral infection of the liver caused by the hepatitis B virus, leading to inflammation, cirrhosis, and, in chronic cases, liver cancer.
A respiratory illness caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, associated with symptoms like fever, cough, and respiratory distress.
A viral infection transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes, causing high fever, severe headache, and joint pain
An infection of the small intestine by Vibrio cholerae bacteria, resulting in severe diarrhea and dehydration.
An infection causing inflammation of the air sacs in the lungs, which can fill with fluid, caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi.
A tick-borne bacterial infection by Borrelia burgdorferi, leading to rash, fever, and joint pain.
A chronic condition where the body is unable to regulate blood glucose levels, leading to hyperglycemia and associated complications.
A condition characterized by persistently high blood pressure, increasing risks of heart disease and stroke.
A chronic respiratory disease causing inflammation and narrowing of the airways, resulting in breathing difficulty.
A progressive lung disease, often linked to smoking, that causes airflow blockage and breathing issues.
An autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the joints, leading to inflammation and joint damage.
A neurodegenerative disorder affecting movement, often including tremors, stiffness, and balance issues.
A progressive neurodegenerative disorder leading to memory loss, confusion, and cognitive decline.
A bone disease that decreases bone density, making bones brittle and more prone to fractures.
An autoimmune disease in which the immune system attacks the protective sheath covering nerve fibers in the central nervous system.
Gradual loss of kidney function, leading to fluid and waste buildup in the body.
Narrowing of coronary arteries due to plaque buildup, leading to reduced blood flow to the heart.
A condition in which the heart is unable to pump enough blood to meet the body’s needs.
An abnormal heart rhythm, which may be too fast, too slow, or irregular.
Occurs when blood flow to part of the brain is interrupted, leading to brain cell damage and potential loss of function.
Narrowing of the peripheral arteries, commonly in the legs, due to atherosclerosis.
A genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, caused by mutations in the CFTR gene.
A hereditary blood disorder where red blood cells become misshaped, leading to anemia and pain.
An inherited neurodegenerative disorder that causes uncontrolled movements, emotional problems, and cognitive decline.
A rare inherited disorder causing the progressive destruction of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.
A genetic condition where a person has an extra chromosome 21, causing developmental and physical differences.
A mental health condition characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, loss of interest, and various physical symptoms.
A disorder marked by excessive worry about various aspects of daily life.
A chronic mental disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, and impaired cognitive functions.
A mental disorder causing extreme mood swings, including emotional highs (mania) and lows (depression).
A disorder characterized by intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions).
An autoimmune disease causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in various body systems.
An autoimmune reaction to gluten, leading to damage in the small intestine.
An autoimmune condition causing rapid skin cell buildup, leading to scaling and red patches.
An autoimmune disorder that leads to overactivity of the thyroid gland (hyperthyroidism).
An autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the thyroid, leading to hypothyroidism.
A condition where the thyroid gland produces excessive thyroid hormone, leading to weight loss, rapid heart rate, and nervousness.
A condition in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough hormones, leading to fatigue and weight gain.
A rare endocrine disorder in which the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and aldosterone.
A condition resulting from excessive cortisol, leading to weight gain, muscle weakness, and high blood pressure.
A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts, leading to irregular periods and infertility.
A common disorder affecting the large intestine, causing cramping, abdominal pain, and altered bowel habits.
A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the lining of the digestive tract.
A chronic inflammatory condition of the colon and rectum, causing abdominal pain and diarrhea.
A chronic digestive condition where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing heartburn
Sores that develop on the lining of the stomach, small intestine, or esophagus, often due to H. pylori infection.
A neurological disorder marked by recurrent, unprovoked seizures.
A neurological condition causing intense, throbbing headaches often accompanied by nausea and light sensitivity.
A progressive neurodegenerative disease affecting nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord.
A condition causing temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles.
A neurological disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements and vocalizations called tics.
A chronic skin condition causing redness and visible blood vessels, typically on the face.
A common skin condition characterized by pimples, blackheads, and cysts due to clogged pores.
A disorder causing the loss of skin pigment in patches due to the destruction of melanocytes.
A type of skin cancer that develops in the cells that produce melanin (the pigment that gives skin color).
A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, causing cough, sore throat, and congestion.
A contagious viral illness marked by fever, chills, and body aches
Illness caused by consuming contaminated food, with symptoms like nausea and diarrhea.
Inflammation of the bronchial tubes in the lungs, often causing cough and mucus production.
Infection causing inflammation in the air sacs of the lungs, leading to cough, fever, and breathing difficulty
Inflammation of the stomach and intestines, causing diarrhea, vomiting, and stomach cramps.
A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that doesn’t improve with rest.
A digestive illness causing abdominal pain, bloating, and changes in bowel habits.
A short-term illness following exposure to a traumatic event, resulting in anxiety and shock-like symptoms
An illness involving excessive worry or fear that interferes with daily activities.
A mental illness marked by persistent sadness, lack of interest, and fatigue
A chronic illness where the airways become inflamed, causing breathing difficulties and wheezing.
An autoimmune illness where the body can’t produce insulin, leading to high blood sugar levels.
A metabolic illness where the body doesn’t respond properly to insulin, leading to elevated blood sugar
An immune response to allergens, such as pollen, causing sneezing, itching, and congestion
A condition where sores develop on the lining of the stomach or intestines, often due to H. pylori infection
A long-term illness causing airflow blockage and breathing issues, often due to smoking
A chronic skin illness causing itchy, inflamed patches
An autoimmune illness that leads to rapid skin cell buildup, creating scaly patches on the skin.
A neurological illness with recurrent, severe headaches, often accompanied by nausea and light sensitivity.
A condition where blood pressure in the arteries is consistently elevated.
A condition causing inflammation and pain in the joints, commonly osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis
A gynecological illness where tissue similar to the uterine lining grows outside the uterus, causing pain
A sudden inflammation of the appendix, often causing abdominal pain that requires urgent treatment
Inflammation of the sinuses, often resulting in headaches, congestion, and facial pain
Illness from prolonged exposure to high temperatures, with symptoms like sweating, dizziness, and weakness
A temporary condition caused by rapid travel across time zones, leading to sleep disturbances and fatigue
Illness from reduced oxygen at high altitudes, with symptoms like headache, nausea, and dizziness
A condition triggered by certain types of movement, causing nausea, sweating, and dizziness
Illness from prolonged exposure to cold, leading to shivering, confusion, and fatigue
Skin irritation and damage due to excessive sun exposure, causing redness, pain, and sometimes blisters
A mild to moderate headache often caused by stress or muscle strain around the head and neck
A sensation where the heart feels like it’s pounding or racing, often related to stress or anxiety.
Blockage of the nasal passages, often due to colds or allergies, causing pressure and difficulty breathing
Inflammation of the voice box (larynx), often resulting in hoarseness or loss of voice
Illness due to lack of sleep, resulting in fatigue, poor concentration, and mood changes.
A condition resulting from inadequate fluid intake, leading to dizziness, dry mouth, and weakness.
A temporary illness after excessive alcohol consumption, with symptoms like headache, nausea, and dehydration.
A temporary loss of consciousness often caused by a drop in blood pressure.
Small blisters around the lips caused by the herpes simplex virus, often appearing during stress or illness
A red, painful lump near the edge of the eyelid, typically due to an infected eyelash follicle.
Involuntary contractions of the diaphragm that lead to a “hic” sound, often from eating too quickly or drinking carbonated beverages.
Rapid or deep breathing often due to anxiety, which can cause dizziness and tingling in the fingers.
An overgrowth of yeast in areas like the mouth or genitals, often resulting in itching or discomfort.
A skin reaction characterized by red, itchy welts, usually due to an allergen or stress.
Difficulty in passing stool, often due to dehydration, poor diet, or lack of physical activity.
Non-cancerous growths in the nasal passages that can cause congestion and a reduced sense of smell
A fungal infection of the feet, leading to itching, peeling, and cracked skin.
An uncontrollable urge to move the legs, especially at night, leading to discomfort and disrupted sleep
An ear infection caused by trapped water in the ear canal, leading to pain, itching, and discharge
Pain that radiates along the sciatic nerve, often due to irritation, inflammation, or pressure on the nerve
Discomfort or pain in the stomach associated with eating, including bloating and gas.
A general term for symptoms that resemble the flu, including fever, chills, muscle aches, and fatigue.
Elevated body temperature, often a sign of infection.
A sensation of cold accompanied by shivering, often caused by the body's response to fever, infection, or sudden changes in temperature, as it works to regulate internal body heat
Soreness or stiffness in muscles, sometimes due to overuse or viral illness.
Persistent feeling of tiredness or lack of energy not relieved by rest.
A sensation of unease and discomfort in the stomach with an urge to vomit
Difficulty falling or staying asleep, leading to reduced quality and duration of sleep
Pain or discomfort in the lower or upper back, often due to strain or posture issues
Feelings of worry, nervousness, or unease, typically about an imminent event or uncertain outcome.
A sensation of spinning or losing one’s balance, often caused by dehydration, anxiety, or sudden movement
A burning pain in the chest, often after eating, due to acid reflux.
Difficulty in emptying the bowels, usually associated with hard stools
Pain or discomfort in the head, scalp, or neck, with various potential causes.
Reflex to clear the throat of mucus or irritants, often due to respiratory infection
Discomfort, aches, or soreness in the joints, which can occur in various parts of the body.
Pain or irritation of the throat that can worsen when swallowing.
Pain in the lower abdomen associated with menstruation
Difficulty breathing or feeling of insufficient air intake, sometimes due to physical exertion.
Discomfort or pain in the chest that may stem from various causes, including muscle strain or respiratory issues.
Enlargement or puffiness of a body part, often due to injury or inflammation.
Pain in the abdomen, which can be caused by digestive issues, cramps, or other factors.
Reduced desire to eat, which can accompany other illnesses or stress
Unusual bleeding from the nose, gums, or other areas, often indicative of a clotting issue or injury.
Loss of sharpness in sight, making objects appear out of focus or hazy.
Unusual discomfort when exposed to cold temperatures, potentially indicating thyroid problems or circulation issues.
Sudden, involuntary muscle contractions causing pain, often in the abdomen or limbs.
Trouble moving food or liquid from the mouth to the stomach, potentially due to an obstruction or nerve problem.
Seeing two images of a single object, often due to misalignment of the eyes or neurological issues.
Reduced saliva production leading to a parched or sticky feeling in the mouth.
Pain in or around the ear, often due to infection or inflammation.
Sweating more than is typical, even in cool conditions or without exertion.
Involuntary muscle contractions in the eyelid, often due to fatigue or stress.
Puffiness or enlargement of the face, possibly due to allergic reactions or fluid retention.
The need to urinate more often than usual, potentially due to diabetes or a urinary tract infection.
A lack of strength or energy throughout the body, often linked to fatigue or illness.
Thinning or loss of hair from the scalp or other parts of the body.
A rapid heartbeat that may feel irregular or pounding.
A change in the voice that sounds raspy, strained, or softer than usual, often due to laryngitis.
Sudden feelings of warmth, often over the face and neck, sometimes accompanied by sweating.
A sensation that causes a desire to scratch, often due to dry skin or allergic reactions.
Discomfort in the jaw area, which can be related to teeth, joints, or nerve issues.
A feeling of being about to faint or lose balance, often due to dehydration or low blood pressure.
The inability to perceive flavors, often associated with viral infections or nerve damage.
Difficulty in moving muscles smoothly, often accompanied by soreness or pain.
Excessive mucus dripping down the back of the throat from the nose.
Loss of sensation or feeling in a part of the body, often due to nerve damage or poor circulation.
Unusually light skin tone, often a sign of anemia or poor circulation.
A severe, throbbing pain in the head, often described as pulsating.
Red, inflamed, or irritated skin that may be itchy or painful.
Perception of a ringing, buzzing, or hissing sound in the absence of external noise.
Involuntary, rhythmic muscle movements, often due to neurological issues or anxiety.
A decrease in the usual sounds of air movement during breathing, indicating possible lung issues.
Abnormal changes in skin color, such as yellowing (jaundice) or bluish tints (cyanosis).
Difficulty pronouncing words clearly, often due to neurological conditions or intoxication.
Difficulty or pain in moving the neck, often associated with muscle strain or meningitis.
Enlarged lymph nodes, often tender to touch, indicating infection or immune response.
A pins-and-needles feeling, often due to nerve compression or damage.
Increase in body weight without changes in diet or activity, possibly linked to hormonal issues.
A decrease in body weight without effort, often a sign of illness or malnutrition.
The expulsion of blood through vomiting, indicating possible gastrointestinal bleeding.
Excessive tearing, often caused by irritation or infection.
A high-pitched whistling sound during breathing, often due to airway obstruction or asthma.
Medications used to treat bacterial infections by killing bacteria or inhibiting their growth.
Medications designed to treat viral infections by inhibiting the replication of viruses.
The use of drugs to kill or slow the growth of cancer cells
The use of high-energy radiation to destroy cancer cells or shrink tumors
Treatment that boosts or modifies the immune system to fight diseases like cancer or autoimmune disorders.
Exercises and physical interventions to improve movement, strength, and reduce pain after injury or illness
Therapy to help individuals develop or regain the ability to perform daily activities after injury, illness, or disability
A form of psychotherapy that helps individuals manage mental health conditions by changing thought patterns.
A medical procedure involving an incision to repair, remove, or treat internal conditions.
Administration of a vaccine to stimulate the immune system to protect against infectious diseases.
A treatment to remove waste, toxins, and excess fluid from the blood when the kidneys are not functioning properly.
Replacement of damaged or destroyed bone marrow with healthy bone marrow cells.
Use of insulin injections or pumps to manage blood sugar levels in people with diabetes.
Tailoring a diet to manage or treat a medical condition, such as diabetes or food allergies.
The delivery of extra oxygen to the lungs to treat conditions like COPD or hypoxia.
Medications that prevent blood clots or treat existing clots.
Medications that block histamines to treat allergies, hives, and itching.
Use of corticosteroids to reduce inflammation in conditions like asthma or arthritis.
The use of medications like acetaminophen, NSAIDs, or opioids to relieve pain.
Medications to treat depression and other mood disorders by balancing brain chemicals.
Replacement of hormones, such as estrogen or testosterone, to manage symptoms of hormonal imbalance
Medications used to prevent or reduce the frequency of seizures.
Medications that relax airway muscles to improve breathing in asthma or COPD patients.
Transferring blood or blood products into a patient to treat conditions like severe anemia or blood loss
Various forms of talk therapy to treat mental health disorders, such as anxiety or PTSD.
Intravenous delivery of fluids to treat dehydration or provide nutrients and medications.
Removal of dead or infected tissue to promote healing of a wound.
Treatment focused on relieving symptoms and improving quality of life in serious illnesses.
Drugs like ibuprofen or naproxen used to reduce inflammation and pain.
Medications such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen to reduce fever.
Devices delivering medication directly to the lungs, used for asthma or other respiratory conditions.
A psychiatric treatment involving electrical stimulation of the brain to treat severe depression or bipolar disorder.
A treatment for sleep apnea that keeps airways open using constant airflow.
A traditional treatment using thin needles inserted into specific points on the body to alleviate pain or promote healing.
Manipulation of soft tissues to reduce pain, improve circulation, and relieve stress.
Creams, ointments, or patches applied to the skin to treat localized conditions like rashes or pain
Medications to prevent or treat nausea and vomiting.
Application of sterile material to protect a wound from infection and promote healing.
Drugs to treat fungal infections like athlete’s foot or ringworm.
A procedure to insert a small mesh tube into a blocked artery to keep it open.
Artificial devices used to replace missing limbs or other body parts.
Treatment involving extreme cold to remove abnormal tissues, such as warts or certain skin cancers.
Structured programs to restore function and health after surgery, injury, or addiction.
The process of removing toxins from the body, often used in addiction recovery.
Injections to reduce inflammation in conditions like joint pain or tendinitis.
Use of focused light beams to treat skin conditions, remove tumors, or improve vision (e.g., LASIK).
Manual adjustment of the spine and other joints to relieve pain and improve function.
Insertion of a device to regulate abnormal heart rhythms.
Medications to neutralize stomach acid and relieve indigestion or heartburn.
Therapy to improve thinking and memory skills in people with brain injuries or neurological conditions.
Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber to treat conditions like decompression sickness or non-healing wounds
Use of acoustic waves to treat chronic pain or improve healing in musculoskeletal injuries.
Treatment using stem cells to repair or replace damaged tissues or cells.
Injection of concentrated platelets to promote healing in injuries or conditions like tendinitis.
A surgical procedure to relieve pressure on the median nerve in the wrist.
Implantation of electrodes in the brain to treat movement disorders like Parkinson’s disease.
A technique to train patients to control physiological functions like heart rate or muscle tension through feedback devices.
The use of water in various forms (hot baths, whirlpools) for pain relief and relaxation.
A procedure using shock waves to break up kidney stones or gallstones.
Insertion of a small balloon into a blood vessel to widen it and improve blood flow.
A traditional treatment using suction cups on the skin to increase blood flow and reduce muscle tension.
Drugs used to treat psychiatric conditions like schizophrenia or bipolar disorder by altering brain chemistry.
Treatments like nicotine replacement or counseling to help patients quit smoking.
Modifying or replacing defective genes to treat genetic disorders or certain cancers.
A traditional treatment still used in specific modern contexts, like treating hemochromatosis or polycythemia
A minimally invasive surgery to diagnose or treat knee joint problems.
Surgical creation of an opening in the trachea to assist with breathing.
A procedure that uses heat from radio waves to destroy abnormal tissue, such as in heart arrhythmias or cancer.
Weight-loss surgeries like gastric bypass or sleeve gastrectomy for obesity management.
Electrical stimulation of nerves to relieve pain or improve function, often used for chronic pain or epilepsy.
A type of dialysis where waste is filtered through the lining of the abdomen instead of using a machine.
Use of beneficial bacteria or yeasts to restore gut health, often after antibiotic use.
Custom-made braces or inserts to support and align the body, often used for orthopedic conditions.
Deliberate cooling of the body to reduce brain damage after cardiac arrest or stroke.
A gentle massage technique to reduce swelling and improve lymphatic flow.
Use of sedatives to help patients relax during dental procedures.
Implantation of a device that stimulates the vagus nerve to treat epilepsy or depression.
Insertion of an intrauterine device that releases hormones for contraception or to manage menstrual disorders.
Use of laser energy to break up stones in the urinary tract.
Use of extreme cold to destroy abnormal tissue, such as warts or certain types of cancer.
A surgical incision made in the perineum during childbirth to prevent tearing.
A procedure to minimize the appearance of scars and restore skin function.
Use of compression garments or devices to improve circulation and treat conditions like lymphedema or varicose veins.
Non-invasive brain stimulation using magnetic fields to treat depression or anxiety.
A nonsurgical treatment to relieve pressure on spinal discs, often used for herniated discs.
Exercises and therapies to strengthen pelvic floor muscles and address incontinence or pelvic pain.
Gradual exposure to allergens or triggers to reduce sensitivity and allergic reactions.
Moving hair follicles from one part of the body to another to treat baldness or hair loss.
Infusion of antibodies to boost the immune system in autoimmune or immunodeficient conditions.
Injections of anesthetics or steroids near nerves to reduce pain or inflammation.
A minimally invasive procedure to treat brain aneurysms by filling them with coils to prevent rupture.
Replacement of damaged or diseased corneal tissue with healthy donor tissue.
Use of specific wavelengths of light to treat conditions like jaundice in newborns or seasonal affective disorder.
Techniques to change unhealthy behaviors, often used for conditions like obesity or addiction.
Designing and fitting personalized prosthetic limbs for improved function and comfort.
A surgical procedure to treat retinal detachment by indenting the sclera.
Use of wearable devices to track blood sugar levels in real time for diabetes management.
A minimally invasive procedure to remove blockages and improve sinus drainage.
Surgical removal of the tonsils, often to treat recurrent infections or breathing problems.
Use of sound waves or music to reduce stress, improve sleep, or manage tinnitus.
A blood test that evaluates overall health and detects a variety of disorders, such as anemia, infection, and leukemia, by measuring red and white blood cells, hemoglobin, and platelets.
Measures glucose, calcium, and electrolyte levels, as well as kidney function markers like blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine.
Includes all BMP tests and additional markers for liver function, such as albumin, bilirubin, and liver enzymes (ALT, AST, ALP)
Measures levels of cholesterol and triglycerides in the blood, including LDL (bad cholesterol) and HDL (good cholesterol), to assess cardiovascular health.
Measures levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) to evaluate thyroid gland function.
Reflects average blood sugar levels over the past 2-3 months, used to diagnose and monitor diabetes.
Measures the time it takes for blood to clot, used to evaluate clotting disorders or monitor anticoagulant therapy.
Evaluates the function of certain clotting factors, often used to monitor heparin therapy.
Examines urine for physical, chemical, and microscopic properties to detect infections, kidney disease, or metabolic disorders.
Includes tests like ALT, AST, bilirubin, and alkaline phosphatase to assess liver health.
Measures inflammation in the body, often elevated in infections or chronic inflammatory conditions.
Measures how quickly red blood cells settle at the bottom of a test tube, indicating inflammation or infection
Detects bacterial or fungal infections in the bloodstream
Measures fibrin degradation products in the blood, used to detect blood clots such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE).
Measures the amount of stored iron in the body, used to diagnose anemia or iron overload.
Measures the level of vitamin D in the blood to evaluate bone health and calcium metabolism.
Detects antibodies associated with rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases.
Identifies autoantibodies often present in autoimmune disorders like lupus.
Detects antibodies or antigens associated with HIV infection.
Detects streptococcal bacteria, the cause of strep throat.
Measures human chorionic gonadotropin hormone in blood or urine to confirm pregnancy.
Analyzes bone marrow samples to diagnose conditions like leukemia or anemia.
Measures PSA levels in the blood to screen for prostate cancer or monitor treatment.
Measures oxygen, carbon dioxide, and pH levels in arterial blood to assess lung function and acid-base balance.
Measures levels of sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate in the blood to assess hydration and electrolyte balance.
Detects small amounts of albumin in urine, an early indicator of kidney disease.
Identifies the type of bacteria or fungus causing an infection and determines the best antibiotic for treatment.
Measures blood sugar levels to diagnose and monitor diabetes.
Detects proteins released into the blood during a heart attack, used for diagnosing acute coronary syndromes.
Measures an enzyme released during tissue damage, used to assess cell injury or death.
Measures enzymes produced by the pancreas to diagnose pancreatitis.
Measures thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and reflexively tests T3 and T4 if TSH is abnormal.
Detects specific allergens by measuring IgE antibodies in response to potential triggers.
Measures the proportion of red blood cells in the blood, used to diagnose anemia or polycythemia.
Evaluates protein levels in the blood, an indicator of liver or kidney health and nutritional status.
Measures enzyme levels released by damaged muscles, often elevated in heart attacks or muscle injuries.
Measures PTH levels to assess calcium regulation and parathyroid gland function.
Measures BNP levels to evaluate heart failure severity.
Measures folic acid levels in the blood to detect deficiencies, often linked to anemia.
Identifies pathogens in mucus to diagnose respiratory infections like pneumonia or tuberculosis.
Measures the concentration of solutes in the blood to assess hydration status and electrolyte balance.
Assesses average blood glucose levels over 2–3 months, a key metric for diabetes management.
Measures B12 levels to evaluate nutritional deficiencies or pernicious anemia.
Detects hidden blood in stool, a possible sign of colorectal cancer or gastrointestinal bleeding.
Detects antibodies that may cause hemolytic anemia or issues in pregnancy.
Measures zinc levels in the blood, used to detect deficiencies that may affect immune function and wound healing.
A group of blood tests that assess liver function and include bilirubin, ALT, AST, and ALP.
Measures cortisol levels in blood, saliva, or urine to assess adrenal gland function and diagnose Cushing's syndrome or Addison's disease.
Detects drugs, alcohol, or toxins in the body for medical or forensic purposes.
A series of tests to detect and differentiate between types of hepatitis (A, B, C, etc.).
